prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
Title: The Glimmergrog's Grotto

Beware the glimmergrog, my friend!
The snickering sprite, the underpass's end!
It lurks within the shadows deep,
A-whispering secrets for its keep.

So grab your trusty lumiflare,
And don your finest aerowear.
Tread lightly through the darkling maze, 
To seek the beast in grimy haze.

Beware its clattering claws, my dear,
Which scrape and scratch both far and near.
The Oriflip awaits its prey,
Do not fall victim to its sway!

But hark! A shuffle in the dark!
The glimmergrog emerges from its nook.
It shivers, shakes, then lets out cry:
"Flumwoggle-wump! Time's nigh!"

With heart abeat and resolve strong,
You face the beast with courage throng.
The underpass's eerie glow,
Illuminates the beast below.

A flash of steel, a whirling leap,
Your trusty blade does swiftly sweep.
The glimmergrog, now fallen low,
Its reign of shadow brought to woe.

Returning triumphant from the depths,
From whence came whispers and behests.
A hero now, you stand a-glow,
Having dispatched the underpass foe.

But hush! For as the tales are told,
Another glimmergrog may yet unfold.
Beware the underpass, my friend,
Its secrets hidden 'round each bend.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
Morgentau Miasma

'Beware the Mistwraith's murky mire, my son!
The fog that cloaks the dawn's first light.
Beware its reaching, grasping hands, and run—
Beware its chill, its flightless fright!"

He took his vorpal sword in hand,
The blade that gleamed with purpose grand.
And sought the monster of the mist,
Determined to resist, resist!

Through swirling fog he ventured far,
The Mistwraith lurked with breath that hissed.
The hero's heart beat like a war,
His sword held fast by trembling wrist.

"O frabjous day! The Mistwraith slain!"
He cried at last, his foe at bay.
The fog dispersed beneath the strain,
And morning's light did brightly play.

“Behold the vanquished vile foe’s fall!
Come, gather round and raise a cheer!
The Mistwraith’s reign of fright is done.
Let joy resound for all to hear!”

And so it was that morn once more,
When fog had lifted from the moor,
And peace returned to land and shore,
The Mistwraith vanquished evermore.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
In the Gloom of Déjà Vew
'Twas gimble in the lorken groove
And the Morphish mome atrope;
Beware the Vewish shrove, my dove!
With tongue that twists and trope.

He seeks the seeker, ’twas revealed,
And snares them with his charm,
Fell alswooping! Rave and reeled,
To wend your mind from jam.

“Beware the Vewish yawn," I heard,
“Thy flighty thoughts to fray;
For if once spied, you're but a word
That bids the mind allay.”

Vorpal in hand, I stood so staunch,
All mimsy were the jards.
I bimbled 'gainst my creeping blanch
And sought the Vewer's shards.

Then as I warbled with the breeze,
Came whiffling through the briar,
The Vewer grinned, my head to seize
And left me quite admire.

“O Vewish shrove!” I, swift unsheathed
My snicker-snack and struck
The mome was rife with Vewish wreathes
That snarked, no bleat nor cluck.

“Has tumbled?” asked the Vewer "Yes,"
“Callooh! Callay!” I tripped.
I dashed his smileful zantiness,
That sought to leave me gripped.

’Twas gimble in the lorken groove
And the Morphish mome atrope;
Beware the Vewish shrove, my dove!
With tongue that twists and trope.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
Title: The Snicker-Snackler

Beware the snicker-snackler's trail, my friend,
Where twisted tendrils tempt and twine.
Of steps unseen and tales untold,
In shadowed glades of moss and mold.

"Tis time to face the snicker-snack,
Prepare thyself for journey grand,
With clobber-clank and whiffling pack,
Set forth with heart and steady hand.

Then lo! The wheezing snicker-snack,
A creature, sly and slumberous,
Engage the beast with snick and snack,
Vanquish it with mind auspicious.

Thy journey done, thou hast prevailed,
Return victorious to the throng.
Rejoice with dance and song proclaimed,
The snicker-snackler's trail is gone. 

Yet still, beware the snicker-snackler's trail,
Where twisted tendrils tempt and twine,
For steps unseen and tales untold,
May yet remain in glades of old.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
Title: The Snarkling Snoozefest

Beware the corporate conference beast!
The sprawling Snarkling snoozefest, fraught with fright.
It festers in the room of yawn and waste,
And lurks to drain the passion, day and night.

In coats of tweed and collars stiff and tight,
We venture forth, our laptops armed and ready.
The clacking keys, a chorus of-click sounds bright,
We heed the siren call of the unsteady.

"Prepare yourselves!" the wise ones chant in verse,
For here lies danger: boredom's dread embrace.
The lulls and yawns, a slow and tortuous curse,
The Snarkling's grasp, the soul it seeks to chase.

With stifled breath and stifled thought we enter,
And wield our weapon: caffeinated brew.
For in the distance, a flicker appearing,
The Snarkling, lurking, comes whirling into view.

The electronic beast, with eyes aglow,
Whispers a lullaby of endless charts.
With PowerPoint vigor, it reels its show,
And thus begins the draining of our hearts.

We fight, we thrust, we feign to stay alert,
As others wilt and breathe the sleep's soft kiss.
And just as we are gripped and almost subvert,
In triumph, we slay the Snarkling with a twist.

A sip of coffee, a sudden burst of life,
The beast is banished to the room's dark corner.
We gather 'round, our laughter ringing rife,
For now we've known the strength of the warrior.

The Snarkling slain, we leave with cheerful glee,
Our spirits soaring, tales of victory grand.
But beware the corporate conference beast still,
For in the shadows, it waits with outstretched hand.
label: high
